importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which Stanton posted threatening TikTok videos, beginning in August and continuing into October, forming the basis of the criminal charges.

keyTakeAways: Andrew Stanton, a 38-year-old man from Kenosha, Wisconsin, was charged with threatening to assault, kidnap, or murder a U.S. official after posting multiple threatening TikTok videos urging violence against Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents.
Stanton allegedly called for ICE agents to be shot and killed, including a direct statement: 'If they (ICE) show up to your neighborhood…it’s time we start shooting at you.'
He also allegedly suggested that mass shootings could be used against federal agents and referenced the September 10 murder of Charlie Kirk, saying 'do a lot more Charlie Kirks.'
The investigation was initiated by the Wisconsin Statewide Intelligence Center after a tip about a request for information on Israeli military locations in Illinois and Wisconsin.

Federal law enforcement attempted to contact Stanton multiple times, including a direct message from a US Customs and Border Patrol supervisor on September 11, which prompted a hostile response and further escalation.
Stanton pleaded not guilty to the charges and is currently in federal detention pending trial, with a scheduled trial on December 15, 2025.
This case reflects broader national concerns about attacks on federal immigration agents and the growing online radicalization that may stem from political and ideological tensions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A 38-year-old man from Kenosha, Wisconsin, Andrew Stanton, has been charged with threatening federal law enforcement agents, particularly Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) officers, after posting a series of TikTok videos between August and October 2025. In these videos, he called for ICE agents to be shot and killed, made references to the September 10 murder of conservative political activist Charlie Kirk, and advocated for mass shootings against federal officials. The investigation began after a tip from the Wisconsin Statewide Intelligence Center, which flagged a request for information on Israeli military positions. Federal agents attempted multiple times to contact Stanton, including a direct message from a US Customs and Border Patrol supervisor on September 11, which resulted in a hostile exchange. Stanton pleaded not guilty and remains in federal detention pending a trial scheduled for December 15, 2025. This case underscores growing national concerns over attacks on federal agents and the role of social media in spreading extremist ideologies.
title: Wisconsin man charged after posting TikTok videos calling for the killing of ICE agents, prosecutors say
